hobby.message: Antique typewriter giving you trouble again?
Urban exploring with that homebrew again?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I explore the city's underground. It's a different world down there.
neutral_answer: Feel off? Maybe. Hard to say these days.
Spent some time in the tunnels again last week.
My hobby: poking around old cables and vents.
Let’s just say things weren’t as quiet as before.
Yeah, whole city’s off lately.
Went out for my usual underground walk—my hobby, that is.
I check old utility tunnels, see what’s changed.
This time, more people wandered down than I’m used to seeing.
Probably just folks testing their new ‘amnesty’ freedoms.
Feels weird, yeah. I stick to my hobby—urban exploring the closed places.
Spent last night in some power conduits under Feltsyn block.
Usually just me and the echoes down there.
Ran into a lot of others—first time in years.
The big amnesty got half the city poking around off-limits zones.
Guess everyone wanted to feel out where the boundaries moved.
Yeah, off is the word for it.
I’ve got this thing for exploring utility passages, ever since my state days.
Most times it’s all rust, silence, me and a bottle.
Last trip, half my old crew was down there—everyone freed up by that fake amnesty.
Suddenly even the old chess crate made an appearance.
Didn’t last. System started flagging some of them again, mid-session.
Never seen so many comm alerts in one tunnel—like someone was watching the whole time.
You notice it too? Place feels upside-down.
I spend my nights exploring city tunnels—keeps me sane after a day of repair jobs.
Started back when I handled routing for the Directorate. Old habits, you know.
Last week, tunnels I hadn’t seen unlocked in years were suddenly open—BCI glitches from that staged amnesty.
Whole forgotten crew appeared out of nowhere, like we called a reunion by accident.
We shared a bottle, caught up, tried to ignore system alerts.
But the peace didn’t last—restrictions snapped back on for a few mid-conversation.
The city never lets you forget it’s watching, not even underground.
hobby_answer: Yeah, still wandering here and there.
Access got strange after the amnesty chaos—locks that shouldn’t open, opening.
Seeing more people below than usual, not sure I like it.
Systems keep shifting. Enough to make you slow down.
Don’t know how long it’ll last.
Yeah, I still get out now and then.
With all the BCI resets, places kept opening and closing overnight.
Ran into a couple groups last week, not the usual types.
People moving quick before doors lock again.
Feels like everyone’s tense, watching scores more than tunnels.
Doesn’t feel as quiet down there lately.
Been treating me well enough, I’d say.
Lately, thanks to the whole amnesty mess, access has been odd.
Old tunnels suddenly open, then locked again in hours.
Ran into half my neighbors under the old marketplace last Friday.
People celebrating their “freedom,” nervous about losing it again.
Strange energy—like everyone’s in a hurry to remember something.
Makes the hobby feel less private but more alive.
Urban exploration’s been a bit wild these days, honestly.
That so-called amnesty? Shook loose every old lock and security check I knew.
Even places that’d been sealed since Halden was alive popped open for a night.
Half the city’s emerging from hiding, taking back forgotten corners.
Last week in a cable hub—ran into a reunion of ex-flagged folks.
We toasted the system glitching for once, but it didn’t last.
Some got flagged again before the night was done. Felt like borrowed time.
Reminds me why I keep my kit light and exits mapped.
Urban exploration’s got unpredictable, if you want the truth.
Used to be a solitary thing—my flask, my torch, dusty server rooms downtown.
The ‘amnesty’ dropped, and I watched access logs flip on decades-old doors.
Last Friday, the tunnels filled up with people I hadn’t seen since pre-BCI days.
Some had stories about vanished relatives resurfacing on old terminals.
We set up by the same crate we used as kids—almost felt normal.
But by morning, BCI had re-flagged half the group—one click, no appeal.
Felt like the Council was letting us breathe just to see what’d happen.
Makes you wonder, all this “amnesty”—who’s really keeping score.
